Letty Mayer.Action: Puts effort into organizing her belongings meticulously and cares for her cat Beast by speaking to him and attending to his needs.
Considers the cat's preferences and adjusts feeding accordingly.
Bends down to comfort crying child despite being pressed for time.
Takes a bloody child's hand and helps her, despite the mess on her jacket.
Rushes into a meeting apologizing sincerely for being late due to a student's crisis, showing concern for students.
Clutches briefcase protectively and shows the bloodstain reluctantly, demonstrating vulnerability and honesty.
Monitors children carefully while talking on the phone, showing attentiveness and care towards the children.
Stumbles into a meeting late, trying to cover a blood-stained lapel; awkwardly apologizes and explains the situation.
Despite being late and disheveled, quickly explains the situation honestly and maintains composure to engage with the Superintendent.
Monitors children on the playground attentively while on the phone, displaying vigilance and multitasking skills.
Moves in to break up two boys fighting over the ball.
Blows angry, staccato notes on her whistle at Jenny after a risky move, warns 'You're in trouble, young lady.'
Discreetly waves her sister Ruth over to join her at the restaurant.
Pours her sister Ruth a glass of wine.
Diplomatically breaks up a fight between two boys over a ball.
Successfully communicates important news about her math idea being accepted.
Blows whistle to assert authority and control over a disorderly situation (Jenny doing a dangerous flip).
Manages multiple conversations effectively—on phone with mother and directing others at the same time.
Offers congratulations to Ruth on her engagement.
Displays a frozen smile during the engagement celebration, appearing uncomfortable or distant.
Engages politely in a somewhat awkward social situation by congratulating Ruth, though her smile is described as frozen, indicating discomfort or unease.
Encourages Paul, acknowledges his achievements, hugs him and suggests celebrating.
Sensually caresses Paul's shoulders and expresses desire to be with him.
Agrees to listen attentively to Paul's deposition questions, shows support and interest.
Successfully secures funding for her math program from the Superintendent.
Directs Paul to put his clothes in the closet for better order.
Initially continues coloring her multiplication chart instead of giving Paul her full attention.
Responds to Paul's request for full attention by putting down the chart and sitting up straighter, showing focus and supportiveness.
Gently but firmly stops Bobby from disrupting the class, apologizes for turtle incident.
Notices Ruth crying outside, signals class to wait, and quickly leaves to comfort her sister.
Comforts Ruth, promises to help with family conflict, and reassures her emotionally.
Corrects Bobby by reminding him of the scheduled grammar lesson and the rules for show-and-tell, demonstrating classroom management and adherence to structure.
Intervenes quickly when Bobby tries to remove the turtle from the bag, showing assertiveness and control over the situation.
Manages the classroom by instructing students to work independently while attending to her sister's urgent emotional need, indicating multitasking and prioritization.
Signals to the students to wait and sets the turtle bag down carefully, showing thoughtfulness and maintaining order.
Leaves the class abruptly to comfort her crying sister, demonstrating emotional responsiveness but also potentially disrupting the class.
Engages in a comforting conversation with Ruth, promising to resolve family tensions and take initiative by planning to speak with both parents.
Cuts off Zach repeatedly and criticizes his writing harshly, causing him to cry.
Looks vacantly at the children after Zach runs off crying and then buries her face in her hands, showing distress.
Apologizes sincerely to Zach, saying 'I'm very, very sorry'.
Shows a conciliatory gesture by changing the class activity to collage day after Zach's distress.
Motivates children to join a creative activity and assigns Zach a responsibility.
Calls in sick, showing vulnerability and admits tiredness to Paul, even starts crying.
Takes care of a child’s bloody nose and inventively creates a collage for the child, demonstrating practical caregiving and creative initiative.
Responds bluntly and dismissively to praise with 'What the fuck. It's my job.', showing a lack of social tact but confidence in her role.
Sits on the ground crying and making a pyramid out of tissues, showing emotional distress and inability to effectively manage stress at that moment.
Navigates a busy bridal shop, confidently orders coffee and pastry, and interacts casually with the clerk and Ruth, demonstrating social ease and situational adaptation.
Compliments Ruth sincerely on dress, showing sisterly pride.
Helps clean up and pick up discarded dresses, being considerate.
Self-conscious about showing stress but reassures Ruth everything is under control.
Assures Ruth that everything is under control despite stress, and confirms preparations for the engagement party are mostly complete.
Actively helps Ruth by picking up and hanging dresses, advising to try on dresses promptly to avoid missing good options.
Shares supportive and confident compliments with Ruth to boost her confidence.
Shows visible signs of stress and self-consciousness when questioned, indicating some vulnerability.
Takes a gown at her mother's urging despite initial reluctance, asks for Ruth's opinion, tries on the dress to please others.
Peers around frantically looking for her mother and Ruth but remains calm and composed.
Takes the gown and tries it on despite initial hesitation.
Becomes frantic and appears somewhat disoriented when her mother and Ruth are not present.
Pushes back her veil and calmly sits down to drink cold coffee while waiting.
Offers her mother a glass of champagne upon arrival.
Warmly greets her father and his wife Monica, expresses gladness they came.
Introduces her parents to each other, attempting to ease tension.
Passes hors d'oeuvres to guests and makes a lighthearted comment ('It's mushroom-time, folks') to ease atmosphere.
Politely offers champagne to her mother upon arrival.
Introduces her estranged parents to each other carefully, attempting to ease tension.
Maintains composure amid an awkward and tense family encounter.
Passes hors d'oeuvres and interacts casually with guests to keep the atmosphere light.
Makes a light joke about identifying a cooking ingredient to deflect tension.
Proposes martinis to celebrate and immediately begins preparing them, organizing tasks between herself, Paul, and Ruth.
Keeps track of meal preparation details, knows the souffle is already in and reminds others about basting the squab.
Realizes she bought the wrong olives after starting to prepare the drinks.
Insists on specific olives for the meal, showing care for the details of hospitality.
Bangs cupboards frantically, becoming wild-eyed, and rushes out to get more supplies to ensure the dinner goes well.
Turns a 'best school marm look' on Paul to get a loan, signaling sincerity and straightforwardness to get help.
Paws through shelves knocking things over frantically, oblivious to the mess and disruption she is causing.
Refuses to leave when asked by manager, pushes manager away forcibly, causing further disruption and attracting security.
Smiles uncomfortably when nervous but tries her best on the cognitive test.
Responds politely and sincerely to Michael's questions without irritation.
Pauses before responding to sensitive questions, showing thoughtfulness.
Answers orientation questions correctly, remembers items after a few minutes, admits to nervousness and corrects mistakes.
Makes a calculation error in subtracting 6 from 85, but recognizes and fixes it.
Responds clearly and confidently to questions about hallucinations and compulsive behaviors.
Sorts her clothes and underwear by color rather than pattern without apparent stress.
Questions the importance of how she sorts clothes, showing some dismissiveness.
Admits it has been a while since she did something she enjoyed, showing honesty.
Sits rigidly, dresses and makes up herself, writes in her organizer, showing self-care and organization despite circumstances.
Responds to Dr. Emlee's questions with some skepticism and humor about frequency of interviews.
Honestly denies hallucinations when asked.
Demands to see her mother immediately despite rules, refuses to wait.
Sinks back on pillows, winded and emotionally vulnerable after being told the rules and about her anxiety.
Insists on seeing her mother immediately despite hospital rules.
Questions the situation and shows confusion about the nature of the place and patient's status.
Eventually sinks back on pillows, overwhelmed by the information and situation.
Stops in her tracks at the sight of the dining hall, says she is not hungry, mentions her mother is coming to get her tomorrow.
Answers questions politely about being a teacher, but does not actively engage in joining group conversation or initiating interaction.
Nods understandingly to Nurse Gates's instructions about rules and routines.
Voices that she is not hungry and appears hesitant at the dining hall.
Tells Nurse Gates that her mom is coming to get her tomorrow, indicating awareness of her situation and plans.
Responds simply when asked about her profession with 'I'm a teacher,' indicating straightforwardness but lacks elaboration or confidence in social setting.
Lets Michael do a card trick for other patients but stares at him coldly and gives a curt remark 'We've met.'
Expresses apology and sorrow to her mother with sincerity: 'I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.'
Letty coldly acknowledges Michael, signaling prior knowledge and a firm demeanor.
Leaves carrying an empty plate after the brief interaction, showing decisiveness but also emotional withdrawal.
Struggles to clearly explain her upset over the missing olives and apologizes to her mother, indicating emotional confusion and difficulty articulating her feelings.
Expresses confusion and inability to absorb the suggestions about staying in the facility
Considers seeking advice from others (Ruth or Paul) on her situation
Refuses help (rejects the duffel bag with clothes) and regresses emotionally
Raises practical concerns about her responsibilities (class, math program, substitute teacher)
Pulls away from her mother while crying, showing emotional distress but not rejecting affection.
Laboriously smooths and refolds every item in her drawer, showing self-care and conscientiousness rather than social warmth.
Fixes her makeup and steels herself before facing others, indicating an effort to present herself well but no direct warmth.
Confronts Michael for taking bets on her diagnosis, expressing hurt and calling out his insensitivity.
Stops herself from entering the noisy room showing anxiety and vulnerability, indicating internal struggle but not an interpersonal warmth indicator.
Carefully unpacks and organizes her clothes, fixes her makeup before facing others.
Confronts Michael about taking bets on her diagnosis with rising voice, showing assertiveness.
Freezes and shows sick realization upon hearing mocking remarks about her OCD.
Defends herself passionately against Michael's provocation, expressing deep personal pain.
Responds with a harsh insult ('Go fuck yourself') after being provoked.
Shows vulnerability by crying alone in her room later, revealing emotional depth.
Sits with arms and legs crossed tightly, appears defensive when group invites her to share.

Looks dangerously close to tears when asked to share about her OCD or depression, indicating vulnerability.
Responds defensively when confronted by group members about her social involvement.
Attempts to deny reluctance to participate in group activities, though appears uncomfortable and close to tears.

Responds honestly and openly to Paul's concerns without defensiveness.

Does not explicitly voice her own thoughts or desires in this excerpt beyond agreement, appearing more reactive than proactive.
